awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Theory of Mechanisms with Unstructured Beliefs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project expands the theory of mechanisms to settings with unstructured beliefs. More specifically, computer science studies optimization problems when the data is at hand, and mechanism design studies optimization problems when the data is in the hands of rational players, who may strategically lie about the data in their possession if this is in their interest. The need for mechanism design arises in many contexts in both computer science and economics, such as distributed computation, auctions, social networks, healthcare, and multiagent systems at large. A player's belief about other players in a mechanism is the information he has about them: it's called "belief" rather than "knowledge" to reflect that the information may not always be correct or consistent. Players' beliefs form the basis of their reasoning, and largely affect the mechanism's structure and performance. Beliefs can be null, purely possibilistic, or purely probabilistic; but, very often, they are unstructured: a player's belief can be anywhere between a set of possibilities and a fully-fledged probability distribution. Despite the tremendous progress made in mechanism design, the vast space where players have unstructured beliefs remains highly unexplored. This project studies fundamental questions about such settings and aims at developing a theory of mechanisms for analyzing and leveraging unstructured beliefs. If successful, it will make profound contributions to both computer science and economics, and is expected to have a long-lasting impact on logic, multiagent systems, and game theory.
 
The technical part of this project consists of two key components. On the one hand, it will establish the logical foundation for different information structures and characterize corresponding notions of rationality. On the other hand, it will develop new tools and criteria for mechanism design, and provide new mechanisms for strategic settings such as auctions. This project will establish a solid scientific foundation for mechanisms with unstructured beliefs, bring mechanism design closer to logic and epistemic game theory, and further strengthen the connections between computer science and economics. Results from this project will be broadly disseminated in computer science, economics, and operations research. The PI will encourage the participation of women and members of underrepresented minority groups in this project. Moreover, new graduate and undergraduate curriculums will be developed based on this project.

por.por_cntn:
The strategic interaction of multiple entities has become a crucial aspect to consider in the design of computer algorithms and mechanisms in the Internet era. Compared to computer systems from many decades ago, where each computer ran individually to execute pre-specified single-machine programs, today's computer systems and networks often have more than one participants interact in a self-guided strategic manner. E-commerce platforms, social networks, and multi-robot systems are all such examples, among many others. The participants include both human beings and artificial intelligence, and their objectives in the same system may vary a lot from one to another. Often, by taking individual actions, they benefit themselves and also collectively achieve the system's goal set-forth by its designer.

Mechanism design, a classic field in economics, has become an important part of computer science in analyzing and designing complex systems. Since what mechanism design tries to achieve is so difficult, proper assumptions are sometimes necessary to simplify the problem and advance the study. In particular, Bayesian mechanism design considers the participants' private preferences as being drawn from some underlying distributions, and assumes that the prior distributions are publicly known. Unfortunately, this *common-prior* assumption almost never holds in reality (Wilson 1985). As another example, the classic theory of mechanism design often ignores the complexity of the system and assumes that it's possible to carry out whatever optimization tasks required by the mechanism to compute the final outcome based on the participants' strategies. Such assumptions, although have greatly advanced the theory, make it difficult to match the scenarios studied by the theory to actual systems. A key focus of this project is to develop the theory of mechanism design with emphasis on the mechanisms' efficiency and robustness, so that the theory better approximates reality. In our studies supported by this award, progresses have been made from several fundamental aspects of mechanism design. In particular:

***We consider, for the first time, the *query complexity* of Bayesian mechanisms. In Bayesian auctions, we only allow the seller to have limited oracle accesses to the players' value distributions, via value queries and quantile queries. Such oracle queries happen a lot in market studies and are also widely seen in databases. They replace the unrealistic assumption that the seller has full access to the value distributions and is computationally unbounded, making the resulting Bayesian mechanisms more operational. A major insight offered by our work is that accessing only ``a small piece'' of the distributions turns out to be enough for achieving good revenue approximations to the optimal Bayesian mechanism, so the gap between the information requirements of the optimal mechanism and the approximately optimal ones is big. Also, our work offers almost matching lower-bounds for the query complexity of approximately optimal Bayesian mechanisms, showing that the constructed mechanisms essentially capture the *correct* way of querying value distributions when designing Bayesian auctions.

***To weaken the common-prior assumption in Bayesian mechanism design, we consider an information structure where the knowledge about the distributions is *arbitrarily scattered* among the players. Not everything is known by the same players, and some distributions may not be known by anybody. The seller doesn't need to know anything about the distributions, neither does he know how the knowledge is distributed among the players. This model isn't even assuming the first level of knowledge (i.e., everybody knows the distributions) and is thus much weaker than the common-prior assumption. In such an unstructured information setting, we design mechanisms for unit-demand auctions and additive auctions that aggregate the players' knowledge, generating revenue that are constant approximations to optimal Bayesian mechanisms with a common prior. A conceptual difficulty here was to find a way to depict the new information structure, which needs to be clean enough to reason about and powerful enough to work with. We thus introduced the notion of *knowledge graphs* and used different graph structures to succinctly represent the scattered information in the system. We then constructed a series of mechanisms that achieve good revenue approximations under different information structures: for arbitrary knowledge graphs, for graphs that are 2-connected, for graphs with in-degrees at least k for any k in {1, ?, n-1} where n is the number of players, etc. Our study thus provides a fairly thorough picture about the relationship between the revenue and the amount of information in auctions, filling the vast gap between the two extremes that are typically considered in mechanism design: the one with a common prior and the one where nobody has any information about the distributions.
